awd_abstract_narration:
Tomography is the mathematics and engineering used to image the internal structure of an object from indirect data.  Tomography algorithms produce images (reconstructions) of the inside of objects from this indirect data.  Important types of tomography include X-ray, sonar, radar, and seismic imaging.  Standard tomographic algorithms work well with complete data--enough data to image the object accurately and stably (for example, X-ray data from views all around the body provides complete X-ray tomography data).  However, many tomographic problems have limited data--some data are missing and standard reconstruction algorithms typically do not image all features of the object and might produce artifacts in the reconstruction.  Added streaks and other artifacts are common in limited data reconstructions, and the results of this project will characterize the artifacts, analyze why they occur, and determine how to suppress them.  This characterization of artifacts will allow researchers to distinguish features of the object from artifacts in the reconstruction.  The research to suppress artifacts will provide algorithms that produce clearer reconstructions in which artifacts are less visible. Direct applications of this research include X-ray tomography, synchrotron imaging, seismic imaging, and radar.  
 
This project focuses on inverse problems in tomography, which allows researchers to image the internal structure of an object from indirect data. There are many effective reconstruction algorithms that utilize complete tomographic data (for example, X-ray data from views all around the body); however, many tomographic problems involve limited data, in which some data are missing. The goal of this project is to develop new mathematical methods in micro local analysis to understand and solve limited data tomography problems. Currently, this paradigm is valid only for limited data sets with smooth boundaries that have specific orientations. The resulting reconstruction methods will be tested on industrial synchrotron data. The investigator will also analyze models for seismic imaging and develop the microlocal analysis of the normal operator and generalizations, including calculating its symbol. This calculation will be used to refine the operator so that the reconstruction highlights object boundaries and is uniform throughout the object. The symbol indicates which object singularities will be visible and which will be invisible in the reconstruction. The operator will be implemented using the approximate inverse and tested on data generated from the wave equation and real data. These methods will also be extended to bistatic radar applications, characterized by a transmitter and receiver flying independently in opposite directions.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of Computerized Tomography (CT) is to provide properties of an object (such as the internal structure of an object) from indirect data (such as from an X-ray CT scanner). Professor Quinto works on the mathematics behind CT, developing and analyzing mathematical models in practical tomography problems and understanding their strengths and limitations. He and his collaborators use this to propose and assess more effective reconstruction algorithms. This research helps others understand what object features they can see from tomographic data.

Prof. Quinto focuses on scientific and industrial problems for which some data are missing--only limited data are given. He uses microlocal analysis (mathematics that precisely characterizes singularities, such as cracks and tumor boundaries) to understand which features of the object are visible from the tomographic data (i.e., can be imaged well from algorithms that use such data) and which features are invisible and cannot be well imaged by the limited data. In addition, reconstruction methods can add artifacts—such as streaks—to the reconstruction that do not belong to the original object. This can help researchers evaluate reconstructions more reliably.

Under this grant, the PI and collaborators analyze seismic imaging with common offset data and the underlying mathematics. They use microlocal analysis to develop a reconstruction algorithm that is not affected by depth as much as the standard normal operator (a standard seismic reconstruction method) in two- and three-dimensions. They considered constant and nonconstant wave speed, proving theorems that will allow researchers to know if one operator is close enough to one that is well-behaved (satisfies the Bolker assumption), then the second one will, too.

 The PI and other collaborators analyze data acquisition methods in Compton scattering tomography that can be used for luggage testing and medical imaging. They proposed a joint X-ray CT and Compton CT data acquisition method for luggage testing that can be obtained using the same X-ray sources at the same time. They prove this joint data provides essentially all the features (wavefront set) about the object being scanned. They develop and test a novel algorithm that gives high-quality reconstructions, illustrating their theoretical results. They also analyzed several other data acquisition methods for Compton CT, Bragg scattering CT, and ultrasound. Quinto and collaborators proved that reconstruction by filtered backprojection (a standard, easy-to-implement reconstruction method) using all Compton data in space will image all features of objects. They analyzed smaller data sets as well.

The PI and colleagues analyzed the implications of patient movement when the operator including the motion is a Radon transform, such as in  X-ray CT. This generalized their results developed under his prior NSF support.

This is all a part of Quinto’s long-term project to develop a more general theory that researchers can use to determine visible features and artifacts in a broad range of limited data tomographic problems. Under this grant, he provides a thorough analysis of filtered-backprojection-type algorithms with arbitrary limited data sets in X-ray CT. This research and the discoveries of his graduate and undergraduate research students help him develop this general theory.

This NSF project directly supported six undergraduates (four women and three from other underrepresented groups) to do research with the PI. They develop and evaluate algorithms and then make conjectures about the results. They discover new types of artifacts and provide insight into their reasons, which he uses to understand mathematically and then prove why they exist. His students learn the underlying mathematical and numerical analysis, and they learn to become researchers themselves and go to mathematics graduate school or industry. He also mentored the research of his two Tufts Ph.D. students as well as three other graduate students during this time. The PI wrote a chapter in Computed Tomography: Algorithms, Insight and Just Enough Theory, a SIAM book for graduate students and beginners in the field, and he gave thirty research talks. These outreach activities enhance and motivate his research. Professor Quinto thanks NSF-DMS for its ongoing support that allows him to be a more effective researcher, mentor, and teacher.
